text: Hey, what's up creators? My name is Luke
and welcome back to the first hour of
Unreal Engine course. In this very quick
video, we're going to be showing you how
we can set up Visual Studio so that way
we have all of the components and the
SDKs, all of the prerequisites
essentially to package our game to
compile it into something that we can
send to our friends. When it comes to
installing Visual Studio, there's lots
and lots of settings in there. And in
this video, we're just going to make
sure you've got everything you need so
that you're set up for success. Let's go
ahead and download Visual Studio. So,
the Visual Studio version that we're
going to be using is Visual Studio
Community. We're going to have a link
for this here,
visualstudio.microsoft.com/d
downloads. Like I said, we're going to
be using the community version, which is
completely free for us to use. So, go
ahead and press download on that. and
then it is going to download a Visual
Studio setup.exe.
Go ahead and click on that and let's
walk through installing Visual Studio
and setting it up. So with this open,
it's now going to start downloading just
the basics of the installer. But more
importantly, in just a moment, we're
going to be asked to configure our
installation. And we're going to do that
together. And now that we've opened up
our setup, we have been asked to
configure our Visual Studio
installation. And again, just to
reiterate, making sure this is set up
correctly the first time round is going
to save us a lot of trouble. So, just
let's go through this together and make
sure we've got all of the correct
components and SDKs. Now, the easiest
way to make sure that our Visual Studio
setup is done correctly is by scrolling
down and we're just going to go to
gaming and we're going to make sure that
we have checked our game development for
C++ as this is going to give us a lot of
the packages that we're going to need to
be able to build and package our game in
Unreal Engine. So, with that selected,
there's a few other things that I want
you to check. First things first, make
sure that your MSVC v143
is going to be ticked. This is your
build tools. This is what's allowing you
to build. Then you've also got the
Windows 10 SDK and the Windows 11 SDK.
We're just going to make sure that we
turn both of these on as well. And then
with that done, that's everything we
need. We can now just go ahead and press
install and let it do its thing. And
with that done, Visual Studio is now
downloading all of those components and
setting up all of those SDKs for us.
This is a completely install now. So,
you can leave this running in the
background knowing that when we jump
into Unreal Engine later on, everything
is set up and good to go. With all of
that being said, move on to the next
video to continue your Unreal Engine
learning journey. But as always, stay
awesome, keep creating.
